arguments.claim: Burden on petitioner to prove Rule 118 infringement; failed to adduce requisite evidence

anchor.surface_text: As the first respondent does not appear himself to have understood the true position under Rule 118 and has failed to adduce evidence requisite for a decision of the question, he must fail,

holdings.text: The election petition filed on May 18, 1954, is within time under Rule 119(a) read with s.10 of the General Clauses Act, as the last day fell on holidays.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that the petition which the respondent filed on May 18, 1954, is entitled to the protection afforded by that section and is in time. We should add that the appellant also raised the contention that if we agreed with him that the election petition was not presented in time, we should hold that the order of the Election Commission admitting the petition was not one of condonation within the proviso to s. 85, because that proceeded on the footing that the petition was in time, and did not amount to a decision that if it was not, there were sufficient grounds for excusing the delay. We are not disposed to agree with this contention but in the view which we have taken that the petition is in time, it is unnecessary to consider it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 119 prescribes a period ('not later than 14 days' equivalent to 'within'); Rule 26 applies General Clauses Act s.10; holidays on last days extend to next working day; harmonious construction with s.81 RPA; rejects distinction in expressions and specific provisos excluding general rule.

holdings.text: There is no contravention of Rule 118 as no finding that the 25 employees were relieved of normal work and put on election work; work was additional/out of hours.

anchor.surface_text: But there is no finding that having regard to the work which they are proved to have done, they must be taken to have been relieved of their original work and put on election work. In the absence of such a finding, it cannot be held that Rule 118 had been infringed. It is possible that the Election Tribunal did not appreciate the true legal position and has in consequence failed to record the findings requisite for a decision on Rule 118, and that would be a good ground on which we could, if the justice of the case required it, set aside the order and direct the matter to be heard afresh and disposed of by another Tribunal in accordance with law. But we do not consider that this is a fit case for passing such an order. The evidence adduced by the first respondent is very largely, to the effect that the appellants men did election work in the morning or in the evening, that is , out of office hours.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies interpretation of Rule 118 to facts: no evidence of supersession of normal duties by election work; Tribunal finding insufficient; evidence shows additional casual work.

holdings.text: Rule 118 requires employment in connection with election for payment, meaning work under contract superseding normal duties (not casual additional work by regular staff).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, neither of these contentions is wellfounded. Rule 118 does not require that the person engaged by a candidate to work in the election should have been specially employed for the purpose of the election. It is sufficient, on the wording of the Rule, that person is employed in connection with the election. At the same time, the requirements of Rule 118 are not satisfied by proving merely that the person does work in connection with the election. That work must be done under a contract of employment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual/purposive interpretation: 'employed for payment in connection with election' requires specific employment contract for election work, relieving normal duties; distinguishes casual/additional work; payment must relate to election employment; reviews English/Indian precedents.

holdings.text: Whether prior employees are 'employed in connection with election' under Rule 118 is question of fact depending on evidence of relief from normal duties.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of Mr. Solicitor- General for the appellant is that the Rule would apply only if the employment of the persons was specifically for work in connection with the election and such employment was for payment... Whether a person who has been previously employed by the candidate on other work should held to have been employed in connection with election is a question of fact to be decided on the evidence in each case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual determination based on nature of work: casual/additional vs. superseding normal duties; burden on petitioner.

holdings.text: Burden on election petitioner to prove infringement of Rule 118; first respondent failed to adduce requisite evidence.

anchor.surface_text: As the first respondent does not appear himself to have understood the true position under Rule 118 and has failed to adduce evidence requisite for a decision of the question, he must fail, the burden being on him to establish that Rule had been infringed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner must establish corrupt practice; inadequate evidence on key fact of employment nature.

holdings.text: No need to consider if Election Commission order was condonation under proviso to s.85, as petition held in time.

anchor.surface_text: We are not disposed to agree with this contention but in the view which we have taken that the petition is in time, it is unnecessary to consider it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter; unnecessary given primary holding on timeliness.

precedents.citation: Sirdar Gurdyal Singh v. Rajah of Faridkote  1

anchor.surface_text: and came in for judicial recognition as such in Sirdar Gurdyal Singh v. Rajah of Faridkote  1 , and, after Independence, became merged in the State of Pepsu. The  1   I894  L.R. 21 I.A. 171. appellant companytinues to retain a large staff of subordinates, and the charge of the first respondent in his petition was that as many as 54 of them were employed for purposes of election, and that Rule 118 had thus been violated. Rule 118 is as follows , No person other than, or in addition to, those specified in Schedule VI shall be employed for payment by a candidate or his election agent in connection with an election.

precedents.case_name: Sirdar Gurdyal Singh v. Rajah of Faridkote
precedents.cited_proposition: judicial recognition of Faridkot as an independent State

anchor.surface_text: That being our view on the companystruction of Rule 118, we shall number proceed to companysider what the position is, on the authorities cited before us. In the Hartlepools Case 1  the question arose with reference to one Butler who was the general secratary of Mr. Furness, the returned candidate, and certain clerks in a companypany in which Mr. Furness, had companysiderable influence. All these persons had taken part in the election. As regards Butler, Phillimore J. observed that if it companyld be held that at the time of his employment his duties included also work in elections if and when they, were held, then a proportionate part of his salary should be regarded as election expenses but, on the facts, he held that it was numberpart of the duties of Butler in respect of his standing employment to be election agent when called upon, and that, therefore, numberpart of his salary need be shown as election expenses. As put by Pickford, J., in Ins companycurring judgment, Butler was paid his salary as private secretary and was number paid anything as election agent .

precedents.cited_proposition: proportionate part of salary of existing employee is election expense if duties include election work; otherwise not
precedents.cited_holding: no part of Butler's salary needed to be shown as election expenses

anchor.surface_text: In view of the remarks of Sankey, J., in the Borough of Oxford Case  2 , in the course of his argument, it is doubtful,,how far the observations of Phillimore, J. quoted above companyld be accepted as good law. They Were, however,. adopted in two decisions of the Election Tribunals of this companyntry, to which our attention was invited by Mr. Chatterjee.

precedents.cited_proposition: remarks doubting observations on business clerks' salaries as election expenses

anchor.surface_text: They Were, however,. adopted in two decisions of the Election Tribunals of this companyntry, to which our attention was invited by Mr. Chatterjee.In the Amritsar Case 1 , the following observation occurs We also companysider that if any man in the service of the respondent were put on election work, their wages for the period should have been shown in the return.  See Hartlepools Case 2  . The words put on election work in this passage suggest that the employees had been taken out of their original work. As there is numberdiscussion of the present question, the authority of this decision is, in any event, little.

precedents.cited_proposition: wages of employees put on election work should be shown in return of election expenses

anchor.surface_text: We also companysider that if any man in the service of the respondent were put on election work, their wages for the period should have been shown in the return.  See Hartlepools Case 2  . The words put on election work in this passage suggest that the employees had been taken out of their original work. As there is numberdiscussion of the present question, the authority of this decision is, in any event, little. In Farrukhabad Case 3 , this passage,, as also the observations of Phillimore, J., were quoted, and in accordance therewith, it was held that the salaries of Tilakdhari Singh, Kundan Singh and Drigpal Singh for the period they worked in companynection with the election of the respondent Nol should have been shown in the return

precedents.cited_proposition: reference to support wages for election work

anchor.surface_text: In Farrukhabad Case 3 , this passage,, as also the observations of Phillimore, J., were quoted, and in accordance therewith, it was held that the salaries of Tilakdhari Singh, Kundan Singh and Drigpal Singh for the period they worked in companynection with the election of the respondent Nol should have been shown in the return It was found in that case that Tilakdhari Singh worked exclusively for 30 days in companyctions with the election and Kundan Singh and Drigpal Singh would appear to have similarly devoted themselves to election work for certain periods. None of these cases has companysidered what would amount to employment in companynection with election, when the persons had been previously employed on other work and they throw numberlight on the present question.

precedents.cited_proposition: salaries of employees working on election should be shown in return
precedents.cited_holding: salaries of specific persons for election period should be included

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that the petition which the respondent filed on May 18, 1954, is entitled to the protection afforded by that section and is in time. We should add that the appellant also raised the contention that if we agreed with him that the election petition was not presented in time, we should hold that the order of the Election Commission admitting the petition was not one of condonation within the proviso to s. 85, because that proceeded on the footing that the petition was in time, and did not amount to a decision that if it was not, there were sufficient grounds for excusing the delay. We are not disposed to agree with this contention but in the view which we have taken that the petition is in time, it is unnecessary to consider it.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the, Election Tribunal is set aside and the election petition of the first respondent will stand dismi
passage suggest that the employees had been taken out of their original work. As there is numberdiscussion of the present question, the authority of

edges.explanation: Holding h2 explicitly concludes no contravention of Rule 118, directly addressing issue i2.

anchor.surface_text: But there is no finding that having regard to the work which they are proved to have done, they must be taken to have been relieved of their original work and put on election work. In the absence of such a finding, it cannot be held that Rule 118 had been infringed. It is possible that the Election Tribunal did not appreciate the true legal position and has in consequence failed to record the findings requisite for a decision on Rule 118, and that would be a good ground on which we could, if the justice of the case required it, set aside the order and direct the matter to be heard afresh and disposed of by another Tribunal in accordance with law. But we do not consider that this is a fit case for passing such an order. The evidence adduced by the first respondent is very largely, to the effect that the appellants men did election work in the morning or in the evening, that is , out of office hours.

edges.explanation: h2 finds no employment of 25 excess persons under Rule 118/Schedule VI, addressing i4

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, neither of these contentions is wellfounded. Rule 118 does not require that the person engaged by a candidate to work in the election should have been specially employed for the purpose of the election. It is sufficient, on the wording of the Rule, that person is employed in connection with the election. At the same time, the requirements of Rule 118 are not satisfied by proving merely that the person does work in connection with the election. That work must be done under a contract of employment.
n called upon, and that, therefore, numberpart of his salary need be shown as election expenses. As put by Pickford, J., in Ins companycurring judgmen

anchor.surface_text: The contention of Mr. Solicitor- General for the appellant is that the Rule would apply only if the employment of the persons was specifically for work in connection with the election and such employment was for payment... Whether a person who has been previously employed by the candidate on other work should held to have been employed in connection with election is a question of fact to be decided on the evidence in each case.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the, Election Tribunal is set aside and the election petition of the first respondent will stand dismi

anchor.surface_text: As the first respondent does not appear himself to have understood the true position under Rule 118 and has failed to adduce evidence requisite for a decision of the question, he must fail, the burden being on him to establish that Rule had been infringed.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the, Election Tribunal is set aside and the election petition of the first respondent will stand dismi
